Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed Center for Earthquake Risk Reduction (CERR) aims to protect lives and infrastructure from the devastating effects of earthquakes through development of tools and strategies to reduce their impact. CERR will solve industry relevant and challenging problems, while providing educational opportunities for students, which are multi-disciplinary in scope. The initial university members of CERR will be the University of California, Berkeley (UCB), the California Institute of Technology (CIT), and the University of Washington (UW). These three institutions already have a close partnership in the rapidly evolving area of Earthquake Early Warning (EEW) including having industry partners contributing to that development. Building on this existing partnership kernel, CERR will expand its mission beyond earthquake early warning, attract additional industry and government partners, and welcome additional university partners. This planning grant proposal seeks to fund a two-day planning workshop between the industry, government, and university groups (UCB, UW, and CIT) to map out an initial research agenda, agree on center policies, and establish the Industry Affiliates Board (IAB).

The CERR would be in the unique position to bring together industrial, government, and academic expertise to advance the field of earthquake risk reduction. The critical challenge is to translate discoveries in earthquake science into actionable information, which impacts businesses, government sectors, and the public at large. This will be accomplished through the development of real-time information feeds, enhanced research for site-specific risk reduction (including path effects), physics-based rupture scenarios, the integration of low-cost sensor data, and analysis of the mechanics of induced earthquakes.

The overarching vision is to push the state of the art in available data and knowledge areas to significantly impact risk mitigation both before and after a large rupture. The I/UCRC framework provides an important mechanism to bring together diverse groups who share common interests, but who have not historically had a method to leverage their individual strengths. Working together, there is a high potential for broad impacts on the challenge of risk reduction. CERR will also train the next generation of student researchers in an environment with an exposure to a broad range of business and government sectors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
BSL, Caltech, and UW currently collaborate within the rapidly developing field of Earthquake Early Warning (EEW). When we began the Planning Grant for an I/UCRC for Geoscience: Center for Earthquake Risk Reduction, the EEW research effort was on the brink of providing earthquake alerts seconds to tens of seconds prior to damaging ground shaking along the US west coast. We began developing a joint center with the overarching vision to protect lives and infrastructure from the devastating effects of earthquakes by better understanding the science behind them. The impetus behind creation of an I/UCRC, as opposed to seeking pure research grants was that industry has billions of dollars of infrastructure and product at risk in the next big earthquake. A Center for Earthquake Risk Reduction, with an initial focus on EEW, was seen as a prudent partnership that could reduce that exposure.

 

Research was, and is still needed to improve the detection, prediction, and alerting systems in order to improve industrial application of the warnings. At the time of the award, incipient industry/university collaborations were rapidly crystallizing to fill this gap. In the time that has past, these partnerships have grown, but outside the framework of the I/UCRC. We had hoped that the proposed Center would build on this development by formalizing these collaborations and expanding them.

 

All I/UCRC Principle Investigators attended the bootcamp meetings with the NSF and learned best practices for starting a collaborative center with industry. We met with our Evaluator and he was helpful in guiding our focus towards industry engagement. The project PIs met and drafted marketing materials, project descriptions, and sought out interested private companies that had an interest in attending the planning meeting and learning more about the concept. We also spent time on the University side, ensuring that the faculty and administrations supported the creation of the center.

 

While setting up the project descriptions, it soon became clear that there were some projects that held such importance to the function of the Center, that it would be impractical to set them to a vote, which was a key requirement for the I/UCRC. Industry engagement was critical for success, so we needed to give them ownership of the process. Speaking with the outside industry groups, we also soon came to realize that while our research themes were centered on the development of earthquake risk reduction strategies, including: rapid earthquake detection and characterization, hazard prediction and alerting, rapid post-earthquake assessment, and physics-based earthquake scenario simulation, those were more university research focused, and not necessarily what industry was interested in. We were confident that the by-products of that research would be of great interest, but the day-to-day problems that would be solved through this collaboration may not have aligned with their ‘pain points’.

 

It has been a long process, but after much deliberation and discussions with our user base, we have decided to not go forward with the planning meeting for the NSF I/UCRC that we were awarded (I/UCRC IIP-1362166). It was an important project to pursue, and we learned a lot, but find that it was not financially viable. The reasoning is that our exploratory efforts with companies did not lead us to believe that we would have a high probability of success in setting up the center.  This, in turn, was due to the continuing discussion about public funding for a public early warning system.  Companies are not keen to commit funding to the I/UCRC when they think there is a good change that the federal government will fund such system in the coming years.
